@crwildman rating is based on the rip that it is, not against other rips. Why would you rate a cam or TS vs a blue ray. Think about it moron.

If your DVD is an aspect ratio of 4:3 then DVD's use (Europe) 720 x 576 pixels and all NTSC (north American) DVD's use 720 x 480 pixels. This means a perfect aspec 0.  Perfect.   And, since we must resize in blocks of 16 x 16 pixels, this makes the following the closest sizes. Remember that the closer to 1.33:1 it is the more exact the aspect ratio to a 4:3 TV screen.  This would be the perfect ratio,  and a 10/10.  
720 x 544	1.32:1    Anyways, not going to waste any more time feeding the trolls.   A/9 V/9  Thanks for the Upload, great quality as always from you.
**aspec 0 = aspect ratio

Just FYI: The ratings should be based off the format the file is in, if its DVD then a rating of 1/1 would be the worst DVD quality you've ever seen, a rating of 10/10 would be considered perfect DVD quality rip, if the format was Bluray then again a rating of 1/1 would be the worst Bluray quality and a rating of 10/10 would be considered perfect Bluray quality rip, it wouldn't make sense to have the same rating for all formats, get it, its not fucking rocket science people.

@crwildman 

1. Bluray is not the highest quality atm even , Moron.

2. The quality of the "upload" where you are commenting is based on a meter of 1-10, its not compared to any other upload or format, Moron.

3. The raw output format is Bluray doesnt mean it has a set resolution or same encode routine as others. Most movies these days use top notch direct encoders that use cuda cores right away and may perform bad on a generic pcs on entry lvl gfx cards when downgraded to generic bluray single or double pass rips. That doesnt mean its a shyt bluray rip or anything. Moron.

Why do you guys keep saying "1/1", "2/2", "5/5", etc.? That's the exact same as "10/10", they both equal 1/100%/whatever. I'm guessing you're trying to say "1/10" with the "1/1", however it does get slightly confusing.

@Infecthead, The rating goes from 1-10 for both Audio & Video (A/V), the first number rates the Audio quality, the second number rates the Video quality.
